ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Cell biology studies concerned with understanding the functioning of lymphocytes._Response; a bodily process occurring due to the effect of some foregoing stimulus or agent._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Consisting of cell surface type I membrane Delta, Epsilon, Gamma, Zeta, and Eta protein subunits with ITAM domains and noncovalently associated with the disulfide bound heterodimeric alpha/beta and gamma/delta TCR, the CD3 complex couples receptor antigen recognition to signal transduction pathways during T-cell activation. During TCR engagement with MHC-associated antigen on host cell surfaces and synapse formation, CD3 activity leads to Tyr-phosphorylated CD3 subunits, Tyr phosphorylation of LAT colocalized in lipid rafts, and MAPK activation. CD3 signal transduction appears to involve LCK, ZAP70, Nck, SLA, SLA2, and DOCK2. CD3 subunits may also associate with the cytoskeleton. CD3 also mediates TCR signal transduction during the developmental transition through positive selection of immature thymocytes to mature CD4+ or CD8+ T cells. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: A protein complex comprised of one T-cell surface glycoprotein CD3 delta chain (CD3D), one T-cell surface glycoprotein CD3 gamma chain (CD3G) and two T-cell surface glycoprotein CD3 epsilon chains (CD3E). CD3D, CD3G and CD3E are transmembrane proteins with one extracellular immunoglobulin domain and one intracellular ITAM domain. The CD3 complex is a T-cell co-receptor that noncovalently associates with either the disulfide bound heterodimeric alpha/beta T-cell receptor (TCR) or gamma/delta TCR and two copies of the accessory protein, T-cell surface glycoprotein CD3 zeta chain (CD247), which is a transmembrane protein with three ITAM domains. The TCR moiety of the TCR-CD3 complex binds to MHC and processed antigens on antigen presenting cells, which triggers phosphorylation of and cellular propagation of the signal by CD247 and the CD3 complex.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mannose-binding lectin originally isolated from jack-bean, Canavalia ensiformis.  Concanavalin A is potent lymphocyte mitogen and a stimulator of matrix metalloproteinases, thereby exhibiting immunostimulatory effects.  It is used in the characterization and purfication of glycoproteins.

Concepts.definition: A mannose-binding lectin originally isolated from jack-bean, Canavalia ensiformis. Concanavalin A is a potent lymphocyte mitogen and a stimulator of matrix metalloproteinases, thereby exhibiting immunostimulatory effects. It is used in the characterization and purification of glycoproteins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A serious infectious disorder that follows wound contamination by the Gram-positive bacterium Clostridium tetani. The bacteria produce a neurotoxin called tetanospasmin, which causes muscle spasm in the jaw and other anatomic sites.: Any substance that appears foreign or potentially adverse to the body and elicits immune response.

Concepts.definition: A serious infectious disorder that follows wound contamination by the Gram-positive bacterium Clostridium tetani. The bacteria produce a neurotoxin called tetanospasmin, which causes muscle spasm in the jaw and other anatomic sites.

Any substance, generally a protein, that stimulates the immune system and elicits an immune response.  Recognition by the immune system elicits either a T-lymphocyte response, recognizing processed antigens, or a B-lymphocyte response, producing antibodies that bind to unprocessed antigens.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genus of yeasts in the phylum Ascomycota. Many species of this genus are endosymbionts of animal hosts.: Any substance that appears foreign or potentially adverse to the body and elicits immune response.

Concepts.definition: A genus of yeasts in the phylum Ascomycota. Many species of this genus are endosymbionts of animal hosts.

Any substance, generally a protein, that stimulates the immune system and elicits an immune response.  Recognition by the immune system elicits either a T-lymphocyte response, recognizing processed antigens, or a B-lymphocyte response, producing antibodies that bind to unprocessed antigens.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A group of proteins isolated from the roots of pokeweed, Phytolacca americana, with hemagglutination and mitogenic properties.  Pokeweed mitogen is particularly mitogenic for lymphocytes and also agglutinates erythrocytes.

Concepts.definition: A group of proteins isolated from the roots of pokeweed, Phytolacca americana, with hemagglutinating and mitogenic properties. Pokeweed mitogen is particularly mitogenic for lymphocytes and also agglutinates erythrocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A class of lectins, found in beans, with hemagglutination properties. Phytohemagglutinin binds to complex oligosaccharides containing galactose, N-acetyglucosamine and mannose, causing agglutination of most mammalian red blood cell types.  It induces mitosis and affects cell membrane permeability, thereby facilitating protein transport.

Concepts.definition: A class of lectins, found in beans, with hemagglutination properties. Phytohemagglutinin binds to complex oligosaccharides containing galactose, N-acetylglucosamine and mannose, causing agglutination of most mammalian red blood cell types. It induces mitosis and affects cell membrane permeability, thereby facilitating protein transport.
